content.rendered:
Electronics play a major role in everyone’s everyday lives if we closely look into our daily lives we will
found ourselves surrounded more by electronic gadgets than by fellow humans. In such an era of heavy
usage of electronics to ensure that our environment is protected from its hazardous waste, scientists
have now developed fully recyclable printed electronics.


“Silicon-based computer components are never going away, and we don’t expect easily recyclable
electronics like ours to replace the technology and devices that are already widely used,” said Aaron
Franklin, Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Duke. “But we hope that by creating fully
recyclable, easily printed electronics and showing what they can do, that they might become widely
used in future applications.”


There is an ever-growing pile of discarded electronic devices that don’t work anymore. Part of the
problem is that electronic devices are difficult to recycle. While scraps of copper, aluminum, and steel
can be recycled, the silicon chips at the heart of the devices cannot.

As people worldwide adopt more electronics into their lives, the amount of discarded electronics
increased exponentially. According to a United Nations estimate, less than a quarter of the millions of
pounds of electronics thrown away each year are recycled. The problem is only going to get worse, as
the world upgrades to 5G devices and the Internet of Things (I.O.T.) continues to expand.


Engineers now have developed a completely recyclable, fully functional transistor made out of three
carbon-based inks that can be easily printed onto paper or other flexible, environmentally friendly
surfaces. The path to recyclability opened with the development of a wood-derived insulating dielectric
ink called nano cellulose.


The team developed a method for suspending crystals of nano cellulose that they extracted from wood
fibers. Crystals on a sprinkling of a small amount of table salt, yield ink that performs as an insulator in
printed transistors. Using the three inks in an aerosol jet printer at room temperature, all-carbon
transistors perform well enough for use in a wide variety of applications, even six months after the initial
printing.


Printed electronics will help not only to reduce electronic waste but will also reduce the price of
electronic items. The electronics after their use can be fully recyclable and we need not create them
again. It will also reduce the usage of plastic required to develop new electronics thus reduces plastics
pollution to the environment.

DWIJSINH H GOHIL

AUTHOR
EC 4th Sem

Naman Rajani

In such an era of heavy usage of electronics to ensure that our environment is protected from its hazardous waste, scientists have now developed fully […]

content.rendered:
Why is it that the left glove simply won’t fit the right hand as well as it fits the left? In science, this property is referred to as chirality. Left hands and right hands are almost perfect mirror images of each other. But whatever way they are twisted and turned, they cannot be superimposed onto each other. Just like hands are chiral, molecules can be chiral, too. In fact, most molecules in the cells of living organisms, such as DNA, are chiral. Unlike hands, however, that usually come in pairs of left and right, the molecules of life almost exclusively occur in either their “left-handed” or their “right-handed” version. They are called homochiral, as researchers say. This molecular homochirality is a characteristic property of life or a biosignature.

“When light is reflected by biological matter, a part of the light’s electromagnetic waves travel in either clockwise or counterclockwise spirals. This phenomenon is called circular polarization and is caused by the biological matter’s homochirality. Similar spirals of light are not produced by abiotic non-living nature,” says the first author of the study Lucas Patty, who is a MERMOZ postdoctoral researcher at the University of Bern and member of the NCCR PlanetS. Measuring this circular polarization is challenging because the signal is quite faint and typically makes up less than one percent of the light that is reflected. To measure this, as part of the MERMOZ project, a team of scientists from the University of Bern and of the National Centre of Competence in Research (NCCR) PlanetS developed a dedicated device called a spectropolarimeter. It consists of a camera equipped with special lenses and receivers capable of separating the circular polarization from the rest of the light. They have now succeeded in detecting this signature from a distance of 2kilometers and at a velocity of 70 kph. Jonas Kühn, MERMOZ project manager of the University of Bern and co-author of the study that has just been published in the journal Astronomy and Astrophysics, says: “The significant advance is that these measurements have been performed in a platform that was moving, vibrating and that we still detected these biosignatures in a matter of seconds.

“Using this device dubbed as FlyPol, they demonstrated that within mere seconds of measurements they could differentiate between grass fields, forests and urban areas from a fast moving helicopter. The measurements readily show living matter exhibiting the characteristic polarization signals, while roads, for example, do not show any significant circular polarization signals. With the current setup, they are even capable of detecting signals coming from algae in lakes. The next step the scientists now hope to take is to perform similar detections from the International Space Station (ISS), looking down at the Earth. That will allow them to assess the detectability of planetary-scale biosignatures. This step will be decisive to enable the search for life in and beyond our Solar System using polarization, and it can also offer valuable complementary information in Earth remote sensing

content.rendered:
Engineers at the University of California San Diego have created a four-legged soft robot that doesn’t need any electronics to work. The robot requires a constant source of pressurized air for all its tasks, including its controls and locomotion systems.

Soft Robot requires complex components like circuit boards, valves, and pumps –outside the robot’s body. The components, that constitute the robot’s brains and nervous system, are commonly bulky and expensive. Whereas the UC San Diego robot is controlled by a lightweight, low-cost system of pneumatic circuits, made up of tubes and soft valves, onboard the robot itself. The robot can walk on command or in response to signals it senses from the environment.

The robot’s computational ability mimics mammalian reflexes. Those are driven by a neural response from the spine rather than the brain. The team was inspired by neural circuits found in animals, called “central pattern generators”. It comprises very simple elements that can yield rhythmic patterns to control motions like walking and running. “This work represents a fundamental yet significant step towards fully-autonomous, electronics-free walking robots,” says, a Ph.D. student of UC.

The robot is equipped with three valves acting as inverters that cause a high-pressure state to spread around the air-powered circuit. The robot’s four legs have three degrees of freedom powered by three muscles. They are angled downward at 45 degrees. It is composed of three parallel, connected pneumatic cylindrical chambers with bellows. When a chamber is pressurized, the limb bends in the opposite direction. That affects, the multi-axis bending coerced for walking. Researchers paired chambers from each leg diagonally across from one another, facilitating the control problem.

A soft valve switches the direction of rotation of the limbs between counterclockwise and clockwise. That valve acts as what’s known as a latching double pole, double throw switch — a switch with two inputs and four outputs, so each input has two corresponding outputs it’s connected to. That mechanism is a little like taking two nerves and swapping their connections in the brain. In the future, researchers want to improve the robot’s gait so it can walk on natural terrains and uneven surfaces. This would allow the robot to navigate over a variety of obstacles.

content.rendered:
Energy is the most fundamental factor around which life has evolved over the millions of years of its existence. It’s retention and transmission have led to the evolution of both mankind and the universe itself. Especially in the Information Age wherein every device runs on electrical power, the importance of the control of these two factors has increased exponentially. Today everyone has a small 5.6-inch small rectangular device which they use to exchange information. The device excels in fulfilling most of their basic information exchange needs but lacks in terms of its energy retentive capacity and has high production cost. After years of research, scientists have finally found a solution to both of these problems.

Researchers from the University of California – San Diego have discovered an extremely efficient battery that can store 5-10 times more energy than the state-of-the-art batteries. It has extremely high areal energy density than the standard Lithium-Ion batteries used in our mobile phones which means that its capacity has also increased ten folds. According to the scientists, such high areal density has never been seen before especially in a flexible device.  Another added advantage of this invention is the low production cost and time. While normal batteries need to be manufactured in sterile conditions like a vacuum, this battery is simply constructed by screen printing AgO. 

Earlier AgO had never been used because it is highly oxidative and chemically degrades quickly. However, scientists at Wang’s lab at UC San Diego were able to find an ink formulation of AgO-Zn that makes AgO viable for printing. As a result, the battery can be printed in only a few seconds once the inks are prepared. It is dry and ready to use in just minutes. And the enhanced flexibility of the battery is a cherry on the top.

The exceptional features of this battery are extremely welcoming for various upcoming futuristic technologies like IoT, 5G, etc. The battery has extremely low impedance compared to the standard technologies which contribute towards its enhanced conductivity. According to the researchers, the battery will also find application in the field of soft robotics due to its power retention capacity as well as its customizability and flexibility. Moreover, this battery also finds usage in stretchable and flexible devices like wearables, for instance, I-watches which we use in our regular lives and require repetitive charging. According to one of their researchers, Lu Yin, “Our batteries can be designed around electronics, instead of electronics needed to be designed around batteries.” These batteries will surely work towards making our devices ready for the technologies of the future.

Mufaddal Suratwala

content.rendered:
Besides knowing the impact of plastic on the environment we have been using it for decades. Cows, birds, turtles, etc. all are eating plastic. But as it is one of the cheapest and convenient products we, humans are using it in our day-to-day life at a very large scale. But the shocking truth about it is, due to this blind use unknowingly we are ingesting a credit card worth of plastic as stated in one research. But, scientists have now engineered an enzyme that can eat plastic at a very high pace.

The most common thermoplastic used to make bottles, boxes, cases, etc. is Polyethylene Terephthalate (PET). It takes hundreds of years to break down if the plastic is left alone. Then, researchers from the University of Portsmouth in England and the U.S. Department of Energy’s National Renewable Energy Laboratory engineered natural PETase in a laboratory that breaks down plastic into building blocks 20 times faster. It reduces plastic infinitely thus reducing plastic pollution. But the disposal rate has increased so much as compared to break down that this rate of disruption is not enough.

But scientists who re-engineered the plastic-eating enzyme PETase have now created an enzyme cocktail which is an amalgamation of PETase and MHETase enzyme. On mixing these two it becomes a ‘super enzyme’. This cocktail can digest plastic up to six times faster. Individually, these enzymes do not have much importance. Professor John McGeehan, Director of the Centre for Enzyme Innovation (CEI) at the University of Portsmouth said that while he was discussing regarding this with Professor Gregg, Senior Research Fellow at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) in the US, they observed that PETase attacks on the surface and MHETase chops the things faster, so if used together they could create miracles.

It is called plastic-eating pac-men as they are combined physically “as two Pac-men joined by a bit of string.” Initially, the discovery of the PETase enzyme heralded the hopes of the plastic breakdown solution but after the discovery of this cocktail, revolution can be brought in plastic degradation. While this cocktail is happily munching plastic, scientists are trying to speed up the breakdown process even faster.

Janki Vaghasiya

title.rendered: Cold Tube will beat the heat

content.rendered:
Summer has filled the veins with light and the heart is washed with noon but the body is soaked with sweat. Summer reminds us of flavorful mouth-watering ice-cream and also a cool breeze when brushes on our face and it feels like heaven on Earth. People beat the summer heat by cranking the air conditioning. It’s reasonably  unhealthy to use air conditioners as they guzzle power and spew out millions of tons of carbon dioxide daily because of which they are expensive and not environment-friendly. They’re also not always good for our health; constant exposure to central A/C can increase risks of recirculating germs and causing breathing difficulties in the long term.  

“The thought of an alternative is inevitable because our technological limitations are finite.” says a team of researchers from the University of British Columbia, Princeton University, the University of California, Berkeley, and the Singapore-ETH Centre who came up with an alternative to this problem. They call it the Cold Tube. The working of this design is clear as it works by absorbing the heat directly emitted by radiation from a person without having to cool the air passing over their skin. This achieves a significant amount of energy savings. 

It has a system of rectangular wall or ceiling panels that are kept cold by chilled water circulating within them. Since heat naturally moves by radiation from a hotter surface to a colder surface, when a person stands beside or under the panel, their body heat radiates towards the colder panel. This creates a sensation of cooling like cold air flowing over the body even if the air temperature is quite high. Scientists say that people get confused between cooling panels and Cold Tube. It is unique as it does not need to be combined with a dehumidification system. They give an example of how a cold glass containing lemonade would condense water on a hot summer day, cooling down walls and ceilings in buildings would also condense water without first drying out the air around the panels. To counter this after effect, they conceived an airtight, humidity-repelling membrane to encase the chilled panels to prevent condensation from forming while still allowing radiation to travel through and also maintaining the air quality. 

This design is ready and used at numerous outdoor spaces like markets, bus stop concerts, and open-air summer fairs in Singapore. Forrest Meggers, an assistant professor at Princeton’s school of architecture and the Andlinger Center for Energy and the Environment appreciated and commented beyond the energy savings, technologies like the Cold Tube have a great future.

title.rendered: New Model for predicting solar flares

content.rendered:
Most of us are generally unaware of the term Solar flares. Actually, a solar flare is a sudden flash of brightness on the sun, usually observed near its surface and in close proximity to a sunspot group. They aren’t a direct threat to humans as the earth’s atmosphere protects us from the radiation of space weather. But if an astronaut out in space is bombarded because of a solar storm he or she might be killed. Another example is from the movie Mission Mangal. Our rocket faced a solar storm which in turn in creased its speed. 


Scientists have developed a new model that successfully predicted seven of the Sun’s biggest flares from the last solar cycle, out of a set of nine. With more development, the model could be used to one day inform forecasts of these intense bursts of solar radiation. 


As it progresses through its natural 11-year cycle, the Sun transitions from periods of high to low activity, and back to high again. Generally, most of us focus on the most dangerous part of the task in order to survive or get through. Similarly, scientists focused on X-class flares, the most powerful kind of these solar fireworks. Compared to smaller flares, big flares like these are relatively infrequent; in the last solar cycle, there were around 50. But they can have big impacts, from disrupting radio communications and power grid operations, too–at their most severe–endangering astronauts in the path of harsh solar radiation. Scientists who work on modeling flares hope that one day their efforts can help mitigate these effects. 


Led by Kanya Kusano, the director of the Institute for Space-Earth Environmental Research at Japan’s Nagoya University, a team of scientists built their model on a kind of magnetic map: SDO’s observations of magnetic fields on the Sun’s surface. Their results were published in Science on July 30, 2020. Solar flares are a sudden explosion of energy caused by tangling, crossing, or reorganizing of magnetic field lines near sunspots. The surface of the Sun is a very busy place. It has electrically charged gases that generate areas of powerful magnetic forces. These areas are called magnetic fields. 


Kusano and his team looked at the seven active regions from the last solar cycle that produced the strongest flares on the Earth-facing side of the Sun (they also focused on flares from part of the Sun that is closest to Earth, where magnetic field observations are best). SDO’s observations of the active regions helped them locate the right magnetic boundaries, and calculate instabilities in the hot spots. In the end, their model predicted seven out of nine total flares, with three false positives. The two that the model didn’t account for, Kusano explained, were exceptions to the rest: Unlike the others, the active region they exploded from was much larger and didn’t produce a coronal mass ejection along with the flare.

Gautam Gandhi

IT sem 3

They aren’t a direct threat to humans as the earth’s atmosphere protects us from the radiation of space […]

content.rendered:
What if someone told you that all the electronic circuits, Integrated circuits and chips that use extended wires and technologies like CMOS, FinFets, etcetra could possibly go obsolete in the near future?
How would you like a soft, circuit-free robot driven entirely using the light of the sun? Researchers from the Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences(SEAS), in collaboration with researchers at McMaster University and University of Pittsburgh, have developed a new platform for all-optical computing, which could replace these electronics.

Present world computation uses hard materials or hardware like metal wires, semiconductors and photo diodes to couple electronics to light. Using the all-optical computing technology, it would be possible to remove the rigid components and control computations solely with beams of light.

To control light with light, researchers decided to use non-linear materials that change their refractive index in response to the intensity of light. When light is shone onto these materials, their refractive index increases, generating their own, light-made waveguide. However, the current technology limited the use of non-linear materials as they required high-powered laser lights or else they would be changed by the transmission of light.

Therefore, researchers developed a completely new material that uses reversible swelling and contracting in a hydrogel under low laser power to change the refractive index. The hydrogel is composed of a polymer network that swells with water, like a sponge, and a small number of light-responsive molecules known as spiropyran; molecules similar to those being used in tint transition lenses. When the gel is illuminated, the area under the light contracts making the polymer dense and in turn changing the refractive index. When the light is removed, the gel recovers its original shape. So when light beams are shone through the material, any two different beams behave as inputs to an optical gate. As an example, Beam A could inhibit Beam B, Beam B could inhibit Beam A, both could cancel each other out or both could go through.

“Though they are separated, the beams still see each other and change as a result,” says Kalaichelvi Saravanamuttu, an associate professor of Chemistry and Chemical Biology at McMaster and co-senior author of the study. “We can imagine, in the long term, designing computing operations using this intelligent responsiveness.”

“Not only can we design photoresponsive materials that reversibly switch their optical, chemical and physical properties in the presence of light, but we can use those changes to create channels of light, or self-trapped beams, that can guide and manipulate light,” says co-author Derek Morim, a graduate student in Saravanamuttu’s lab.

This reversibly responsive material that controls light at exceptionally small intensities holds a promising future and perhaps a technological revolution in the field of materials science.

Snigdha Lokre

EC 5th SEM

How would you like a soft, circuit-free robot driven entirely using the light of the sun? Researchers from the Harvard John A. Paulson […]

content.rendered:
The 21st century is an era of an uncurbed outburst of technological advancements. Artificial intelligence to robotics, renewable energy resources to environment conservation, material engineering to nanotechnology are just a few of the endless technologies of the current era. However, amongst all these, nanotechnology is pivot in the development of all other technologies. Nanotechnology is the manipulation of matter at atomic, molecular and supramolecular scale. As a rule, the most important need in the field of nanoscience is binding atoms and molecules together and more importantly doing it in a controlled manner. However, can a particle bind materials at the atomic scale? Additionally, can it control the bound particles at a constant rate? All these questions lead to one answer and that is “Nanocellulose.”

Recently, researchers from Aalto University, Germany, discovered a unique cohesive property of nanocellulose of binding particles in a constant and controlled manner. But exactly what are Nanocellulose? Nanocellulose are tiny fibrils extracted from plants and recently they have been getting a lot of attention for their strength. In the opinion of the scientists, these minuscule materials have shown a lot of promise in outperforming plastics and even replacing them. On the other hand, the most perplexing fact about them is that they have shown strong binding properties to form new materials with any particle.

The first struggle for any researcher who wants to create materials is to come up with a way to generate cohesion which in turn is extremely particle dependent. Fortunately, nanocellulose has helped them overcome that struggle, as it can overcome any particle dependency. Nanocellulose possesses the ability to form networks at the nanoscale that adapt according to the given particle.

Nanocellulose bind the particles by forming sheet-like structures and also form tiny fishnets to trap smaller particles like nanoparticles. Moreover using them, materials can be moulded into any shape by an extremely simple and spontaneous process that needs only water. Interestingly, they form such networks by following extremely precise scaling laws which make their implementation way easier.

These developments are extremely timely in the field of nanotechnology, wherein combining nanoparticles with bulk materials is of prime necessity. According to researchers, nanocellulose has become a bridge joining laboratory discoveries with current manufacturing techniques. The researchers claim that they will now be able to produce materials from particles ranging from 20-20,000 nanometers in diameter. Moreover, inert particles such as metallic nanoparticles to microorganisms such as baker’s yeast can be compounded, given a different shape from 1D to 3 D and can be converted to hydrophilic or hydrophobic forms. In conclusion, their team leader, Prof. Orlando Rojas, said, ‘This is a powerful and generic method, a new alternative that bridges colloidal science, material development and manufacturing’.

Mufaddal Suratwala

IT 3rd SEM

Artificial intelligence to robotics, renewable energy resources to environment conservation, material engineering to nanotechnology are just a few of the endless technologies of the current era. However, amongst all these, nanotechnology is pivot in the development of all other technologies. Nanotechnology is […]

content.rendered:
As of June 2020, there have been more than 8,000 satellites launched from Earth. These satellites are employed in helping us understand more about our world. One of the ways in doing so is by using cameras to capture the objects of our interest. But due to accelerations and engine operations, the satellites tend to vibrate, hence blurring out the images. The reduction of this vibration is the object of many pieces of research. Vedant, an aerospace engineering doctoral student at the University of Illinois was working on the same problem when he discovered his now patented invention could not only cancel out the vibrations but also rotate the satellite.

The attitude and position of a satellite are controlled using a set of actuators. One of them being-momentum management device which produces attitude changeswithout external torque rather they temporarily alter the distribution of angular momentum in the spacecraft. Along with vibration isolation systems these are known as Attitude Control System (ACS) whose malfunctions have shortened the lifespan of space science missions. The Strain-Actuated Solar Array (SASA) ACS is recently introduced to tackle this problem. They use piezoelectric actuators on strain deployable multifunctional structure panels, and the resulting momentum rotates the spacecraft by small angles that hold a pose for short periods. The core disadvantage is that they must be coupled with other ACS technologies to produce large reorientation and are unsuccessful in balancing out the momentum, to solve this problem Multifunctional Structures for Attitude Control (MSAC) a SASA extension is proposed here. Vedant utilized the transverse oscillations of the deployable panels combined with a reconfiguration of the moment of inertia (MOI) which are achieved by exercising the same set of distributed actuators. Strategic adjustments to MOI (induced due to longitudinal strains) between transverse oscillations produce a secular change in attitude i.e. due to these minor but consistent changes in MOI the angle changes dramatically hence rotating the satellite. 

“I mapped it to the keyboard keys so that each key made it oscillate in one direction,” he said. “I was pressing random keys to see if the system works or not and it did something very unusual. It stopped shaking, but instead of moving back to its original position, it moved to a different place and stopped. I thought that was a mathematical error. So I dug more into it. And it turned out to be a new way of moving the panel.”

Vedant said U of I has obtained a patent on his invention. Since it went public inearly February, there has been a surge of interest in it from companies that design, build, and launch satellites. Vedant plans to continue to develop the technology and eventually license it to companies.

Divyashree Iyer

IT 4th SEM

title.rendered: Phase Changing Materials set to Revolutionise Infrared Vision

content.rendered:
Phase Changing Materials set to Revolutionise Infrared Vision What comes to your mind when you come across the word ‘Night Vision’? Probably hi-tech military gears that you may have encountered when playing First Person Shooter games or watching intense power-packed action movies, right? You may be aware that infrared imaging is the prevalent technology used in ‘Night Vision’. An indispensable part of the technology for controlling the infrared light, infrared optics, hasn’t changed much over several decades since its inception. The bulky moving parts of the infraredoptics delimit the technology to be applied to other small system applications. This can now be changedas Researchers at MIT Lincoln Laboratory and Department of Material Science and Engineering have devised a way to control infrared light using phase-changing materials. The materials can change their optical properties when energy is provided. Changing their refractive index is the fundamental property of these materials in which they are more efficient than the previous system. The team were able to control the infrared light in multiple systems using an entirely different class of materials consisting of germanium, antimony, selenium, tellurium (GSST). The chemical bonds of the material that tie the atoms play a crucial role. In the initial phase state, the material is in a crystalline form where atoms are arranged in an organised pattern. When a short, high-temperature spike of thermal energy is applied, the bonds in the crystal break down and reform in a more random pattern. 

The material can be changed back to the crystalline state by applying a long and medium temperature thermal energy pulse. Generic phase change materials tend to be transparent in one state and opaque in other which prevent the light from being controlled adequately. The researchers tackled this problem by adding selenium to the original material (GST) which led to a dramatic decrease of the material’s absorption of infrared light in the crystalline phase. This resulted in a large difference in the refractive index of the two states. The significant change in the refractive index allows the design of devices without any mechanical parts and with no optical loss. The team has successfully demonstrated its use in infrared hyper-spectral imaging used to analyse images for hidden objects and also in an optical shutter.

The significance of this technology can be better understood by using the example of a laser beam. For changing the direction of the laser beam, in current systems, a large mechanical gimbal would be requiredto physically move the lens to steer the beam. Instead, using a thin-film lens made of GSST, the position can be changed by electrically reprogramming the phase-change materials without the use of any moving parts. The technology has the potential to revolutionise optical, communication and computer industry in unimaginable ways. Energy-efficient optical switches for improved network speed, compact reconfigurable meta-optical devices for infrared zoom are just the tip of the iceberg.

Parth Patel

IT 6th SEM

Probably hi-tech military gears that you may have encountered when playing First Person Shooter games or watching intense power-packed action movies, right? You may be aware that infrared imaging is the prevalent technology used […]

content.rendered:
Recently, the scientists at Stanford and SLAC have successfully created a particle accelerator on a silicon chip that can accelerate electrons at a very high velocity, of about at a fraction of velocity of light. For this experiment, the scientists made use of infrared waves instead of using microwaves as in traditional accelerator.

Usually, the microwaves measure about 4 inches from peak to trough, while the infrared rays have the wavelength of one-tenth of the width of a human hair which proves the fact that infrared light can accelerate electrons in such short distances compared to microwaves. But to accomplish this, the chip’s physical features must be around 100,000 smaller than the copper structures used in a traditional structure.

The team was led by electrical engineer Jelena Vuckovic, who is an electrical engineer led the team. The team created a vacuum channel by carving a nanoscale channel out of silicon and then sealed it.

To conduct this experiment, the team followed inverse design algorithms. These algorithms allowed the researchers to work in a reverse direction starting with the estimated light energy the chip is going to provide and designing the software to build the right nanoscale structures to bring the photons to contact with the flow of electrons.

The basic working of the experiment is to pass the electrons through a channel of a bundle of silicon wires and colliding them at the strategic locations in the canyon walls. Each time the infrared waves are passed, a burst of photons hit a bunch of electrons and thereby accelerating them forward. All of this occurs on a very small surface of a vacuum-sealed silicon chip made by the team.

According to the team, this accelerator-on-chip is just a prototype. The planning and fabrication techniques are often scaled up to deliver particle beams accelerated enough to perform cuttings as experiments in chemistry, mathematical science and biological discovery where the power of massive accelerator is not required.

Also, Vuckovic believes that this prototype accelerator-on-chip is a fully integrated circuit which means that all the critical functionalities required to create acceleration are built right into the chip and thus expanding its scope won’t be a problem.

It is believed that this technology could also lead to new cancer radiation therapies. Also, it’s small size proves to be an advantage. The X-ray machines used in the hospitals fill the room with radiations that’s tough to focus on tumours and which requires the patient to wear lead shields to minimize collateral damage.

Aastha Patel

CE 4th SEM

excerpt.rendered: Recently, the scientists at Stanford and SLAC have successfully created a particle accelerator on a silicon chip that can accelerate electrons at a very high velocity, of about at a fraction of velocity of light. For this experiment, the scientists made use of infrared waves instead of using microwaves as in traditional accelerator. Usually, the […]

content.rendered:
A species made by man. Now doesn’t that sound like something that came straight out of a sci-fi movie? Believe it or not, it’s already here! When humans started playing with technology, they made robots imitating living beings. Now living cells are being incorporated into robotics to make a new sort of device/organism. These living things called ‘xenobots’ are neither old-fashioned robots nor a known species. They’re an entirely new class of artefact: a living, programmable creature.

A team of scientists at the University of Vermont repurposed living cells, scraped from frog embryos to make these unusual living machines. Xenobots get their name from Xenopus laevis – species of the frog that the cells belong to. Using an evolutionary algorithm, a supercomputer designed a myriad of cell structures. On assembling, the cells began working together and body forms emerged that were never before seen in nature. It is similar to reusing the dead cells of a tree to make paper. Xenobots are millimetre wide, they can move, pick up a small amount of load and most significantly, they can heal themselves on being injured. When it’s cut in half, a bot can stitch itself back together, which is not something traditional machines could do.

Researchers have imagined several useful applications of xenobots that the existing machines cannot do. They can be used for detecting radioactive contamination and poisonous compounds in the body travelling inside the arteries, clearing micro-plastic in oceans and many more. Furthermore, a group of these bots can work collectively to perform complex tasks. This technology has major advantages in intelligent drug delivery. Existing technologies make use of toxic materials while xenobots are completely harmless and biodegradable. However, living tissue is weak and it degrades, hence they have a small lifespan.

Despite several applications and vast future possibilities, the inception of these creatures raises ethical concerns and fear. Messing around with complex systems we don’t yet understand, might have severe implications. Should we be exploring these complex systems? Will this innovation cause a butterfly effect and turn into something we can’t handle? Researchers believe that this study on xenobots might lead to consequences that we’re not ready to face.

The world is changing fast with the rapid growth of artificial intelligence, automation and advances in gene modification that can change the course of history. While this might appear daunting and overwhelming, this change could be the rise of a better, beautiful world. Possibilities are many, there is this innate creativity in life, it is up to us to explore it right, in every way we can.

Khadija Sidhpuri

CE 4th Sem

When humans started playing with technology, they made robots imitating living beings. Now living cells are being incorporated into robotics to make a new sort of device/organism. These living […]

content.rendered:
The Portamento​ effect refers to the effect of gliding a note at one pitch into another note at a different pitch, between any two audio signals, an effect creatable only by instruments including the human voice. For researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a colossal feat has been achieved by creating the portamento effect in real-time with the help of an algorithm that uses just math, to blend the musical notes seamlessly.

This work of an MIT student, Trevor Henderson, now a graduate student in computer science, relies on ‘Optimal Transport’, a geometry-based framework that determines the most efficient ways to move objects, or data points, between multiple origins and destination configurations, to create the Portamento effect. Henderson’s paper describing the algorithm has not only won the ‘best student paper’ award at the recent International Conference on Digital Audio Effects, it’s algorithm has flawlessly merged various audio clips, such as a piano note gliding into a human voice, and a song blending into another song. For Henderson, a classically trained organist, who performs electronic music and has been a DJ on MIT’s radio station, this wasn’t too much of a stretch. “When I see a new idea, I ask, ‘Is this applicable to music?’” he says. In work that originated in a class project, it was a triumphant undertaking that he himself came to use to build his own equipments to smoothly transition between songs, on his radio show. Trevor Henderson was aided by Justin Soloman, an X-Consortium Career Development Assistant Professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and also an aesthete cello and piano player.

The applications of optimal transport include supply chains, fluid dynamics, image alignment, 3-D modelling, computer graphics, and more. In computer graphics, one of the ways optimal transport in the algorithm is used is to transform shapes by finding the optimal movement from each point on one shape into another. In addition to this, concepts of signal processing were used too. Musical instruments produce sound through the vibrations of components, like, violin uses strings. These vibrations are captured as audio signals, where the frequency and amplitude represent different pitches. Conventionally, in this theory, it is done with a fade, that is, one signal is reduced in volume while the other rises. On the other hand, Henderson’s algorithm smoothly slides frequency segments from one clip into another, with no fading effect. To do so, the algorithm splits any two audio clips into segments of 50 milliseconds. Then, a Fourier Transform is run, which converts the two segments into their frequency components, which are then lumped together into individual ‘notes’. Then an ‘interpolation parameter’ comes into play, which determines where each note will be on its path, stitching the two signals from starting of one signal to the end of the other signal, thus creating the Portamento effect.

Believably, the algorithm when embedded into equipments could be used by DJs to transition between tracks, and also by musicians and beat boxers who might use it blend instruments and voice in studios.

Snigdha Lokre

EC 4th Sem

For researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a colossal feat has been achieved by creating the portamento effect […]

content.rendered:
It’s a cold winter day. You pick up a cup of steaming hot coffee, but you can’t feel its cosy warmth. You are covered tightly by your blanket but you can’t feel its furry softness. Imagine shaking someone’s hands but not being able to feel the gentle warmth that comes with it. In our daily lives, being able to feel these things is taken for granted. Unfortunately, people with hand amputations have to rely on prosthetics. Though it restores their mobility, prosthetic hands lack the sensory perceptions that are crucial in most activities. Hence, people taking the aid of prosthetics face arduous daily life and social challenges. These problems result in psychological problems like isolation, depression and even suicidal thoughts.

Existing technology uses the help of stretchable electronics to integrate sensory data into prosthetics, but challenges in geometric complexity have resulted in unsatisfactory results. To overcome this problem, researchers at Purdue university, Georgia, have developed a flexible and stretchable electronic glove that can fit on a prosthetic arm easily. The glove reacts to external stimuli like temperature, pressure and humidity. It provides mechanical softness and sensory perception. Furthermore, it replicates the appearance of a human hand and hence, it gives way to seamless physical interaction. Things just got real!

This electronic glove or e-glove is nitrile based. Initially, it is layered with epoxy and conductive silver ink is printed on its surface. Active sensing elements are distributed uniformly over the globe through sequential transfer printing to provide sensory information. To secure the bonds, the glove is put in an oven at 70 degrees Celsius for two hours. This process is repeated several times to form multiple layers consisting of different sensors. Finally, the entire structure is dip-coated in an uncured silicone elastomer to form the outermost layer- the skin. The silicon layer consists of a skin colourant to give a human-like appearance. The glove is accompanied by a specially designed wristwatch for displaying sensory data and transmitting it. To top it all off, the entire process uses cost-effective technologies to minimize initial and maintenance expenses.

Touch is one of our five senses. It is equally as important as seeing, hearing or speaking. Touch is crucial for survival and the lack of it results in a multitude of problems and challenges. For most of us, being able to feel is a part of our ordinary lives and we take it for granted. One can only recognize its significance if they lack it. This electronic glove bridges the gap between prosthetics and real arms. It provides a way for people with amputations to interact like ordinary people and feel complete again. This glove makes prosthetics better than ever before and is a surefire way to change lives.

Khadija Sidhpuri

CE 4th Sem

Imagine shaking someone’s hands but not being able to feel the gentle warmth that comes with it. In our daily […]

content.rendered:
All the snaps that we take daily to increase our streaks count need to be stored somewhere. Such data storages increase our energy consumption. It has been estimated that by 2025 data storage will consume a 5th of our global electricity. To tackle this energy crisis scientists in Lancaster university have made a new type of electronic memory cell known as universal memory, which when used will reduce the peak power consumption by a fifth. Today we use Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) which processes memory at super-fast speed while consuming less energy and flash drives which stores data robustly. The downside is that DRAM needs to be refreshed every few tens of a second since every read operation wipes out the data and in a flash drive, the writing and erasing operations are slow and energy-intensive. Hence, the new device combines the best features of DRAM and flash drive.  

The memory cell is a heterostructure of InAs/AlSb/GaSb. It is akin to a high electron mobility transistor (HEMT) with the charge being stored in a floating gate (FG). The channel, FG and control gate (CG) are made up of InAs. The channel is made junctionless and is uniformly n-doped to compensate for the naturally p-type GaSb. At the InAs/GaSb interface, the InAs conduction band is below GaSb valence band, thus electrons flow from GaSb into InAs. High electron density in InAs channel is responsible for its higher conductance value than GaSb. There is an AlSb barrier between the channel and FG and two InAs quantum wells and three AlSb barrier-together forming resonant tunneling barrier-separate CG and FG. Due to energy and state difference between both the quantum wells, direct electron tunneling between FG and CG is obstructed. Also, when no voltage is applied electrons are confined in FG. In this way, non-volatility is achieved.  

When small voltages are applied to CG, electrons flow out of or into FG as required which indicate read, write and erase function. The scientists applied a voltage of -2.5V and +2.5 to perform write and erase operations respectively. During a write operation, an electron flows from CG to FG subsequently charging FG. On the other hand, during an erase operation an electron flows from FG to CG, depleting FG. The conductivity of a channel depends on the amount of data stored in FG, thus data is read by measuring the drain current. Several read operations can be used together and thus, demonstrating its non-destructive nature. It has been noted that each erase process removed more electrons than a write operation delivered, but no degradations were found after hundreds of operations.  

Due to universal memory’s similar structure to flash memory, its switching energy is quite less compared to its current counterparts. After many experiments, they deduced that its storage time was 10^6 times longer than refresh time of DRAM, while still using 100 times lesser energy. 

This type of memory would enable a new type of computer which would never require booting up but would go to sleep when it isn’t being used-even between keystrokes. It s design also promises device scaling while the peripheral circuitry will be minimized in the memory chip. Potentially though, it would be beneficial for anyone using next-generation electronic devices. Thus, our Netflix streaming won’t drain our energy resources like it does today. 

Divyashree Iyer

IT, 3rd Sem.

It has been estimated that by 2025 data storage will consume a 5th of our global electricity. To tackle this energy crisis scientists in Lancaster university have made a new type of electronic […]

content.rendered:
Most of us take the ability to speak for granted, but it’s a rather complicated process containing motions of mouth and vibration of vocal cords. If the vocal cords sustain injuries, a person can lose the ability to speak. Most mute people cannot speak due to their vocal cord injury. So what’s the solution? Well, the researchers at the American Chemical Society (ACS) have found an interesting way! They have developed a wearable synthetic throat, which when attached to the neck like a tattoo, can convert throat movements into sound.  

Scientists have earlier developed detectors that measure movements on human skin, such as pulse or heartbeat. However, these devices typically can’t convert motions into sounds. A   prototype artificial throat with both capabilities was created, but it wasn’t comfortable enough to wear for long periods. So the researchers wanted to develop a thinner, skin-like artificial throat that would stick to the neck like a temporary tattoo. Compared with the materials used before in acoustic devices like carbon nanotubes and silver nanowires, graphene is a two-dimensional material that is well-known for its high electro-mobility, high ﬂexibility, and low heat capacity. So, graphene has been widely used in strain sensors. 

The scientists suggested a wearable skin-like ultrasensitive artificial graphene throat (WAGT) that combined both sound and motion detection and sound emission in a single device. To make this artificial throat, the scientists laser-scribed graphene on a thin sheet of polyvinyl alcohol. The device measured 0.6 by 1.2 inches or about double the size of a person’s thumbnail. The scientists used water to attach the film to the skin over a volunteer’s throat and connected it with electrodes to a small armband that included a circuit panel, microcomputer, power amplifier, and decoder. When the volunteer soundlessly imitated the throat motions of speech, the instrument converted these movements into emitted sounds, such as the words “OK” and “No.” The researchers say that in the future, mute people could be taught to generate signals with their throats that the device would translate into speech. 

 As a sound detector, the WAGT device shows a very good strain range and an excellent skin adhesion ability. It can recognize the sound signal with the collected waveforms corresponding to every word. The strain of WAGT is caused by throat movements, consisting of vibration of vocal cord and motion of larynx. Finally, a circuit board with the function of transforming sound signals is fabricated and applied to the sound-detection system. All in all, the WAGT can detect the throat movement signals of mute people sensitively and then speak out on behalf of them precisely, which can be helpful for mute people to speak in the future.  

 

Maulik Gandhi

IT, 3rd Sem.

If the vocal cords sustain injuries, a person can lose the ability to speak. Most mute people cannot speak due to their vocal cord injury. So what’s the solution? Well, the researchers at […]

content.rendered:
We all know water is a universal solvent and nothing can stop its flow. Not even the large rocks. It can easily seep through surfaces. That is the reason most of the medicinal drugs are supplied to our body in a water solution. What if the drugs can be provided faster to the affected area than an injection or oral intake? Ever wondered water trespassing the surface at a speed double than cheetah’s speed. The transport of water droplets at the nanoscale allows us to do so without expending any energy. This can help us to solve our day to day life problems in better and efficient ways.

Ermioni Papadopoulou and Petros Koumoutsakos at ETH Zürich, Constantine Megaridis at the University of Illinois at Chicago, and Jens Walther at the Technical University of Denmark have proved how water droplets can move so much faster at the nanoscale. According to them, simply patterning the graphene will let the water droplets flow through its layer at very high speed without expending energy to pump the water through it. The mode of transport is completely different than we see in our day to day life. To create the wettability gradients; ranging from hydrophobic to hydrophilic; graphene surfaces were structurally patterned. Then on the surface water nanodroplets were placed. On the hydrophilic domain, larger contact angles were created and on hydrophobic domains, smaller contact angles were created due to different surface patterns. The forward acceleration of droplets was due to the difference at the advancing and receding end of the water droplets. In the experiment, they observed the velocity of droplets in the order of 100 meters per second. As usual, larger droplets moved slower than the smaller ones due to their inertia and greater friction with the surface.

After studying the transport mechanism of these droplets, they developed a model to predict the trajectory of the droplets based on the scaling law derived by them. According to them, this can be very useful in heat dissipation for nanoscale and microscale systems, efficient drug delivery and electricity generation. They are also trying to experiment these methods with other nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes. Similar surface patterns can also be found in nature. This mechanism is found in the veins of banana leaves and on the surface of Nameeb desert beetles. Nature always has the answers to our problems if we have an eye to look and a heart to care for it.

Lokesh Narwani

EC, 5th Sem.

That is the reason most of the medicinal drugs are supplied to our body in a water solution. What if the drugs can be provided faster to the affected area […]

title.rendered: Shaping Ultra -fast Light Waves Using Nanopillars

content.rendered:
Light, we know it as the mysterious electromagnetic radiation that has kept mankind in wonder for hundreds of years. Although we have come a long way in our quest to demystify light, there are still many things to be discovered that can potentially change the future of mankind itself. Recently, many scientists have been working on ways to control various properties of light. Shaping the light pulses or controlling its properties is very important for applications using optical cords. To increase the functionalities of these high-speed optical circuits as well as extending its applications requires us to control more properties of the ultra-fast light waves. A group of researchers at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and the University of Maryland’s NanoCenter have developed a ground-breaking and efficient method of shaping the light waves to our needs.


Researchers achieved this by first depositing a layer of extremely thin silicon (few hundred nanometers) on glass, then with a protective material they covered an array of millions of minute squares of silicon. The team created millions of minute pillars by engraving the silicon surrounding each square. These nanopillars are the key to shaping the light waves precisely.


The ultra-thin device is an example of a meta-surface which is used to change the properties of light such as amplitude, phase and polarisation of the light wave. This is done by carefully designing the size, density, shape and distribution of the nanopillars, enabling simultaneous and independent tailoring of multiple properties with nanoscale precision. For manipulating phase and amplitude of each frequency component of an ultra-fast wave, they designed individual nanopillars for each constituent colour in the pulse and an integrated polariser assembled behind the device. The light wave slows down when travelling through a set of nanopillars compared to its speed in air and its phase is also delayed. The amount of phase change is determined by the size of the nanopillars whereas the light wave’s polarisation depends on the orientation of the nanopillars. The change in amplitude can be achieved by attaching a device called polariser at the back of silicon.

Alteration of amplitude, phase and polarisation of the light wave in a very supervised manner can be used to encode data. Several chemical and biological processes can be studied as well as modified by tuning fine changes to the nanopillars. For example, to increase or decrease the product of a chemical reaction, alterations in the incoming light waves can be made. Further development in the device may give researchers control over the time evolution of light pulses which can be used to create devices that measure light frequencies used in atomic clock and also to identify planets of distant stars. Thus, this new approach using nanopillars can take us a step further in discovering path-breaking applications using ultra-fast light waves.

Parth Patel

IT, 5th Sem.

Although we have come a long way in our quest to demystify light, there are still many things to be discovered that can potentially change the future of mankind itself. Recently, many scientists have been working […]

title.rendered: Shaping Ultra-fast Light Waves Using Nanopillars

content.rendered:
It wouldn’t be exaggerating to say that electrons rule our world, right? They have even made it to our textbooks. We have learned about electrons and holes in depth in our first-year courses. Now, a research team at The Ohio State University have discovered almost accidentally a material which shows dual roles as both electrons and holes holder.

The concept of dual-personality material wasn’t relevant until the new discovery. We know that electrons have negative charge and holes, which are basically the absence of electrons have a positive charge. Movement of electrons and holes lead to the material conducting electricity. Electrons can be manipulated to radiate or absorb energy. A material can act either as an electron-holder or a hole-holder, but not both. Thus, we need to add layers of different materials to balance the properties to create a practical material. The new material is a crystal (NaSn2As2) which effectively holds both electrons and holes eliminating the need to add multiple layers of different kinds of materials.

This new finding proves wrong the long existing dogma in science that a material can be either an electron or a hole holder, but not both. When a fellow researcher was measuring the properties of the crystal when he observed that the material sometimes acted as an electron-holder and sometimes as a hole-holder. He ran the experiments again and again as something like was not possible previously, but got the same results. The case wasn’t that the electrons became holes because that would be the same assembly of materials. This material when observed keeping one property in perspective looks as an electron-holder but when observed in another way, it looks as a hole-holder.

In the materials which are made by adding layers different materials, the energy travels less efficiently through the structure. This increases the probability of failure in a device made from that material. In the new material which consists of layers of crystals of the same material, the carriers behave as electrons when travelling within each layer but they behave as holes when travelling between two layers. The researchers have named this dual-ability property of the material as ‘goniopolarity’ which occurs due to the unique electronic structure of the material. They also believe that there might be other materials that exhibit this property but are yet to be discovered.

This material opens up the possibility of a whole array of unique devices to be created. It could also simplify the electronics which can lead to efficient systems that are less likely to break down. Since this material can potentially change the way our traditional transistors function, most of the electronics around us can possibly be engineered in a new and more effective way. This includes LEDs in televisions, computers and laptops, solar panels and even the light sensors in our smartphones. Thus, this material has the potential to bring about a revolution in the world of electronics.

Parth Patel

IT, 4th Sem.

We have learned about electrons and holes in depth in our first-year courses. Now, a research team at The Ohio State University have discovered almost accidentally a material which shows dual roles as both electrons […]

content.rendered:
What do you do to send an article from one place to another? Simply use the postal or courier services, right! But what if one had to transport something on a much smaller scale? Nanotechnology comes to the rescue here! Scientists at the Centre for Functional Nanomaterial (CFN) have wrapped a box of a different kind. By using a chemical synthesis method, they engineered hollow metallic nano-sized boxes with cube-shaped pores at the corners. They also demonstrated how these “Nano wrappers” take the job of a postman at nanoscale and can be used to carry and release DNA-coated nanoparticles in a controlled way.

In this research, DNA coated particles were embedded on the nano wrappers. When the DNA fibres contract, the nanoparticles become small enough to fit in the openings and enter the hollow cavity. The nanoparticles can then be sealed within the nano wrapper by decreasing the salt concentration. The scientists also established the transformation of nanocubes to nano wrappers through spectroscopy experiments. Oleg Gang, leader of the research team, compares the nano wrapper with a box of which only the exterior can be used and not the interior. Most nanoparticle synthesis methods used today, produce solid nanostructures. We need approaches to engineer the internal space of these structures. Compared to their solid counterparts, hollow nanostructures has different optical and chemical properties which can be used for a variety of applications.

But what is the use these nano wrappers? The use of nano wrappers in medicine offers some exciting possibilities.  It can be used to make repairs at the cellular level. The treatments that were once only possible by vaccinations can now be made possible by taking the drugs in the form of a pill. Nanoparticles made of polyethylene glycol-hydrophilic carbon clusters (PEG-HCC) can absorb free radicals at a much higher speed than the proteins used by our body for this purpose. This ability to absorb free radicals may reduce the harm that is caused by the discharge of free radicals after a brain injury. They are used for the treatment of many genetic diseases like cancer, Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s etc.

The efficiency of this nanoparticles can be further increased by using the nano wrappers by achieving controlled release of the material. It can also be used for other areas where there is a requirement to release the material inside it in a controlled way. These nano wrappers can revolutionize the normal drug delivery system. However, they are made of gold-silver alloy, so they are bound to be costly. But the researchers are looking forward to replacing the gold-silver alloy with other bimetallic materials and assemble them into large-scale architectures. So, we may be using them in regular treatments very soon!

Maulik Gandhi

IT, 2nd Sem.
